repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
With CPython turning its π series from rc into final, the `coverage_*` end-to-end tests started failing.

It was confirmed that the CI passes with Python 3.14.0rc3 and older. But the final release makes said test crash. This is because it never ran on release candidate of 3.14 — the test-runner skips coverage tests on pre-releases: https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/5b14ba8/runtests.py#L248. Perhaps, that check should allow release candidates too.

The reason for the coverage tests failure is that coveragepy uses `sysmon` engine under Python 3.14 which ends up not printing coverage for the Cython module and the test does not find the filename in the output. But the test also disables sysmon while compiling. The included fix explicitly makes coveragepy use the former default of `ctrace` to be consistent with the Cython-side setting.

It's also failing on `pip install` locally, because PEP 517 build backend is isolated and the context `setup.py` (having said import) is running in does not have access to the "outer" Cython copy. It is unclear why this works in older runtimes.

This patch forces the PEP 517 build to happen with isolation turned off.

comment_data.body: This syntax doesn't work for FT. But that's fine. Sinc non-FT is failing the same way, it'll give us enough indication of whether this was the culprit.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2,28 +2,39 @@
 # tag: coverage,trace
 
 """
-PYTHON -m pip install .
+PYTHON -m pip install --no-build-isolation .
 PYTHON setup.py build_ext --inplace
 PYTHON -m coverage run --source=pkg coverage_test.py
 PYTHON collect_coverage.py
 """
 
 ######## setup.py ########
 
+from sys import version_info
+
 from setuptools import Extension, find_packages, setup
 from Cython.Build import cythonize
 
+sys_monitoring_setting = str(int(version_info >= (3, 14)))  # match coveragepy
+
 MODULES = [
-        Extension("pkg.module1", ["src/pkg/module1.pyx"]),
-        ]
+    Extension(
+        "pkg.module1",
+        ["src/pkg/module1.pyx"],
+        define_macros=[
+            ('CYTHON_TRACE', '1'),
+            ('CYTHON_USE_SYS_MONITORING', sys_monitoring_setting),
+        ],

comment_data.body: Though https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/source_files_and_compilation.html#c-macro-defines suggests using `extra_compile_args` which don't work either.

+        define_macros=[
+            ('CYTHON_TRACE', '1'),
+            ('CYTHON_USE_SYS_MONITORING', sys_monitoring_setting),
+        ],

comment_data.body:
We should probably switch to Py3.14t as the base line for FT Python benchmarks (because it's much more advanced), but that's not a part of this PR.
```suggestion
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -382,11 +382,12 @@ jobs:
         with:
           # List special Pythons first to keep the 'normal' one as (last) "python3.xy".
           python-version: |
+            3.14t

comment_data.body: Why is this needed? I don't think we have any dependencies in this test that would benefit from this option.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2,7 +2,7 @@
 # tag: coverage,trace
 
 """
-PYTHON -m pip install .
+PYTHON -m pip install --no-build-isolation .

comment_data.body: Ok, you mentioned it in your commit message for this change. As I wrote, I don't see a reason for this either, but whatever, it doesn't hurt. Deserves a comment, though.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2,7 +2,7 @@
 # tag: coverage,trace
 
 """
-PYTHON -m pip install .
+PYTHON -m pip install --no-build-isolation .

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
# Install without build isolation as this currently fails in Py3.14.0.
PYTHON -m pip install --no-build-isolation .
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2,7 +2,7 @@
 # tag: coverage,trace
 
 """
-PYTHON -m pip install .
+PYTHON -m pip install --no-build-isolation .

comment_data.body:
@scoder when I was the CI failures, I was trying to repro locally and saw those import errors. So I originally thought this was the root cause. With multiple things failing, I focused on this.
Later, I realized that the traceback I was seeing locally was not happening in the CI but since I was hitting it locally, I figured that other people's local setups might get the same error. I'm not sure why exactly but I do have a user-global pip config with a few options set in it, though I didn't think to check that earlier.

Because this test was failing for me and in the CI, I assumed it was a 3.14 thing. But actually, I was getting this crash on 3.13 locally. So the code comment you added is a little inaccurate.

I later realized that but didn't clarify in the PR description as I was digging into the actual root cause and eventually forgot to document this bit.. Still, I believe this option is useful to keep since it makes the expected pip behavior explicit rather than influenced by something unidentified. The comment just needs to be improved a bit.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2,7 +2,7 @@
 # tag: coverage,trace
 
 """
-PYTHON -m pip install .
+PYTHON -m pip install --no-build-isolation .

comment_data.body: Yeah, I originally thought this would mostly be a PR making it more explicit that the CI now chooses the stable release. That pre-release notion of `-dev` being a pre-release threw me off the right path for a while and I wanted to make sure it's clear in the CI definition.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -382,11 +382,12 @@ jobs:
         with:
           # List special Pythons first to keep the 'normal' one as (last) "python3.xy".
           python-version: |
+            3.14t

comment_data.body:
FTR, this is the config I have:
```ini
$ cat ~/.config/pip/pip.conf
[global]
user = false
require-virtualenv = true

[install]
use-pep517 = true
```

But removing it didn't change anything — the test keeps failing if `--no-build-isolation` isn't passed. This is under pyenv-provided Pythons (3.13.7 and 3.14.0 at least). Within respective virtualenvs.

I'll submit a PR correcting the comment.

Not sure. I guess I'd also have expected them to work here.
But I think they're fine as `distutils` comments in the test files.

commit.message:
🧪 Use `3.14.0(t)-rc.3` in CI

With CPython turning its π series from rc into final, the
`coverage_cmd_src_pkg_layout` integration test started failing.

This patch pins the Python version to rc3 to see if that influences
the CI outcome.

verification.payload:
tree c45fd66061cedc44f66c69dff1aebb84c352a2e4
parent 5b14ba8dad826671ed6e3ca4b61f489bd3be9088
author Sviatoslav Sydorenko <wk@sydorenko.org.ua> 1760012648 +0200
committer Sviatoslav Sydorenko <wk@sydorenko.org.ua> 1760012902 +0200

🧪 Use `3.14.0(t)-rc.3` in CI

With CPython turning its π series from rc into final, the
`coverage_cmd_src_pkg_layout` integration test started failing.

This patch pins the Python version to rc3 to see if that influences
the CI outcome.

commit.message:
Use non-isolated PEP 517 build @ coverage_cmd_src_pkg_layout

Otherwise, importing `Cython` fails on `pip install`. Interestingly,
it somehow works under Python 3.14.0rc3 and older, but not
3.14.0-final, which is currently unexplaintable.

verification.payload:
tree 76330b485a7548417a60bdba56929d84fd484e47

committer Sviatoslav Sydorenko <wk@sydorenko.org.ua> 1760036539 +0200

Use non-isolated PEP 517 build @ coverage_cmd_src_pkg_layout

Otherwise, importing `Cython` fails on `pip install`. Interestingly,
it somehow works under Python 3.14.0rc3 and older, but not
3.14.0-final, which is currently unexplaintable.

commit.message:
Force ctrace cov engine @ `coverage_*` e2e tests

This is to match directives set in the Cython module under Python 3.14.

coveragepy defaults to sysmon [[1]] on Python 3.14 and does not work
with the Cython plugin.

[1]: https://github.com/nedbat/coveragepy/issues/1790

verification.payload:

author Sviatoslav Sydorenko <wk@sydorenko.org.ua> 1760048023 +0200
committer Sviatoslav Sydorenko <wk@sydorenko.org.ua> 1760048425 +0200

Force ctrace cov engine @ `coverage_*` e2e tests

coveragepy defaults to sysmon [[1]] on Python 3.14 and does not work
with the Cython plugin.

[1]: https://github.com/nedbat/coveragepy/issues/1790
